Award.AwardTitle: Enhancing the Broader Impacts of Developing a Social-Cognitive, Multilevel, Empirically-Based Model of Public Engagement for the Shaping of Science and Innovation Policy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
Emerging science and technology (S&T) innovations can trigger public controversies and signal the opportunity to work through competing public values, understandings, and misunderstandings to decide how to reconcile public values with new S&T. One way that Congress (21st Century Nanotechnology Research and Development Act , 2003) and the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy (Open Government Plan, April 7, 2010) have suggested to approach this complicated task is to engage with the public about the ethical, legal, and social issues related to scientific and technological innovations. Currently, a wide range of public engagement techniques are used-including focus groups, public forums and deliberations, surveys, and social marketing. Different forms of public engagement involve different features designed to evoke meaningful public input. However, little is known regarding which public engagement options are effective under different conditions. How should information about scientific or technological innovations be conveyed? Is it better for participants to engage with information individually or in groups? Can and should participants be encouraged to think critically about the information presented? This project seeks to begin to answer these questions by applying insights from psychology and other social sciences to multiple simulated and controlled (that is, laboratory) "public" engagements about complex, cutting-edge, nanotechnology issues. The researchers collected substantial information from these engagement events. The analyses of the data from the engagements will enable researchers, policymakers, and the public to better understand the strengths and limitations of different approaches to public engagements and to build new insights about such engagements.

This project will disseminate data and results from a set of four unique longitudinal studies. Studies were conducted across three- to four-week timespans, and involved more than 1,200 student participants. In each study, different social and cognitive aspects of engagement were experimentally manipulated to assess their impacts on common public-engagement goals. For example, studies varied the design of information about new technologies, and whether participants considered technology-relevant ethical, legal, and social issues individually or in groups. Effects of these manipulations were examined on knowledge acquired about nanotechnology, attitudes toward and perceptions of the development and regulation of nanotechnology, trust in nanoscientists and the policymakers who deal with regulating nanotechnology, and acceptance of policy outcomes. The current project will broadly disseminate each study's findings, as well as facilitate public access by providing detailed descriptions of the manipulated design features and supplementary materials that include the data from the studies, study materials, instruments, and data transformation and analysis syntax in multiple formats. These materials will foster further analyses by other researchers using alternative theoretical perspectives and allow theoretical development on topics beyond nanotechnology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Public engagements increasingly are used to provide input about the policy, legal, ethical, and other impacts of scientific and technological innovations. Yet there is a critical dearth of scientific knowledge concerning which forms, features, and conditions of public engagements are optimal for what purposes, and why. This project focused on the dissemination of data and results from a rare study of the connections between public engagement design features, deliberative processes, and knowledge, attitudes, and other (e.g., trust, policy acceptance) outcomes. Each of the four longitudinal studies disseminated through this project took place over multiple weeks. Together the studies involved more than 1000 student participants. During the studies, social and cognitive aspects of deliberation were experimentally manipulated and numerous mediators, moderators, and outcomes were assessed. The final data sets include a wealth of rich individual and group level data. In this project we prepared and published detailed descriptions of methods and findings across the studies in a single open-access online format. We also prepared and published detailed supplemental files containing the raw data, materials, instruments, and data transformation syntax in multiple formats.

The intellectual merits of this project include (a) easy comparison across studies and discussion of patterns of findings that do versus do not replicate, and (b) fostering further analyses from alternative theoretical perspectives through the dissemination of the exceedingly rich data along with the results. In addition, the additional analyses that were part of this project resulted in a new analytical method for the simultaneous study of different types of attitude polarization and the development of an initial theory of policy acceptance. Using nanotechnology as the focus, and social and cognitive psychological theories and data as guides, this detailed-documentation-plus-supplementary-materials dissemination project is intended to provoke researchers to build on this and other prior work and take the next steps in further developing a theory of public engagement in science and innovation policy. The project findings next can be tested outside the classroom context, in real-world face-to-face and online engagements, and project tools can be used in those tests. By widely disseminating the findings, measures, and exceedingly rich data from experimental manipulations of public engagement, this project allows others not only to learn from study findings, but to mine the data to answer questions that stem from their own unique theoretical perspectives.

The broader impacts of this dissemination project include advancing the impact of the results through presentation as a unit rather than piecemeal as individual journal articles (the approach to date). The open-access format can increase the impact and reach of the research across numerous fields. The findings are expected to impact public engagement research, studies of communication, public administration, political science, applied social/personality psychology, and civics education. Use of an open online supplementary-material format also will allow the wide dissemination of materials for educating and supporting students as they think about ELSI (ethical, legal, and social impacts) pertaining to nanotechnology. Thus, this enhanced dissemination plan also may increase the inclusion of ELSI units in STEM courses more generally. The open-access online format also will draw attention to the data sets, which will be made available for download to encourage others to mine the data, and to provide potential opportunities for training new scholars in experimental methods applied to public engagement contexts.
